reviewText: The first DVD in the "Love" series. This series has no swearing and is great for the entire family and kids to watch because it is an interesting storyline and it also teaches good moral values to families.
I really liked this movie. It made me cry towards the end. Now we know about Missy's mother and what a hard worker she was and such a loving person!!

Keeping in line with the other Love Comes Softly books and movies, Love's Everlasting Courage is a sweet, and at times sad story with the Christian faith woven into every strand of it's fabric.  With themes of endurance and a trust in God it is encouraging and inspiring.

To read my full review and for a chance to win a DVD gift set visit my website:

[...]
this series of movies is wonderful, I love how they have such meaning and faith in them, something I do not see in most movies, great for family movie night

The 411 by Maria:
Since I am new series, this was a big surprise for me and now I must see Love Begins. I believe I hosted a giveaway but never saw it myself.  I love this era of movies. Reminds me of all the years I watched Little House On The Prarie. Julie Mond who plays Ellen for all your General Hospital fans played Lisa Niles for a while. Love her! It was strange seeing Cheryl Ladd as someone's grandma.  Great cast.

When the Davis family's farm takes a hit from the drought, Ellen does what any loving wife would do for her family; she takes a job as a seamstress in town. When Clark's parents come to visit, his mother Irene is concerned that Ellen is working "in my day wives didn't work." Clark's dad, Lloyd played by Bruce Boxleitner completely understands how his son's family is struggling and wants to help the farm.

Ellen is stricken with Scarlet Fever and Clark must be a full time parent to their young daughter Missy, adorably played by Morgan Lily who I fell in love with in 2012 and Flipped.

Clark's parents are the perfect supportive parents we all wish for and through their help, the Davis Family work together through love to keep their hearts open.

What I love most about this movie which was one of Hallmark's highest viewed series is the simplicity and quietness of life, family and love. I was often reminded of Little House on the Prairie and spent some time trying to find out where it was filmed but couldn't find much.

Wonderful family movie about the love of family.

Just so you know that Love begins and Love's Everlasting Courage are prequels. Which means that they take place before the first movie that was made, Love Comes Softly. I wrote one other review for Love Begins and the problem with this movie is the same as that one.  While it's a nice clean movie it just does not pack the emotional oomph of Love Comes Softly.  As with Love Begins there are just unbelievable things in it.  Like they live way out on a ranch and repeatedly run into town for fixin's for dinner, like we would run to the grocery story now.  I don't believe they did that.  I couldn't believe Clark as portrayed in Love Begins because he is such a man of faith and it had him portrayed as not coming from that kind of background.  In this second prequel, they aged Missy's mother, they aged Missy, but Clark is this younger man.  How then does he age so rapidly overnight when Marty comes to town after his wife dies?  I mean Missy is close to the same age, and Clark's still a young kid.  Missy is also taller than the Love's Come's Softly Missy, but the actress has her speaking cantor down.  She just gets shorter and blonder for the next movie?  Aside from casting, my main problem with the movie is with the dialogue, the expressions they use which are just not from that time era, and the fact that you just don't feel as much for the main characters as with the subsequent films.  And as I said on Love Begins, I don't know if that is bad screenwriters or a bad book prequel, but it just isn't as good of a movie.  That aside, the one thing I did enjoy from the movie was getting to know more of the story that led to Love Come's Softly and the other films.  So this one was my second least favorite with Love Begins being my least favorite of all.  I'd watch it again just to know the story line, but that's about it.

This is one of three remaining in the series that I purchased for my wife for Christmas this year.  She is more observant than I but we both agreed that some of the actors chosen to portray characters in later parts of the series do not match up.  For example:  Missy is too tall and older than she is in Love Comes Softly.  Ben and Sarah didn't  match up either as Sarah is either blonde or redhead in this one but later she is obviously a brunet.  Call it picky if you wish - but that is some of our personal observation.  The story itself was good.

I have purched over a few years the 9 DVD 's which come frome frome the Janet Oke series. Family love and high values are at the core of each story.
I loved the movies. it was great to finally watch the beginning movies. I have the complete set now. The books are great as well.

This film has a tough assignment.  It has to build a bridge between "Love Begins" (Clark wins Ellen) and "Love Comes Softly" (Clark is a widower...).

The bridge works; it connects past and future, and makes a good job of it.  It explains how Clark's first wife died, and where he got the firm faith that God will be with us when all our best efforts fail and life is collapsing around us.

It is a sound link in the series, potentially more helpful (though less entertaining) than "Love Begins" and "Love Comes Softly."

This was one of two add-ons to the Janet Oke Pioneer series. I have loved the books and then the videos but adding this as a prequel was not interesting to me nor did I think it enhanced what had already been done well.

Like all of the dvds in this story, this one is top-notch.  Just wish the "powers that be" in the movie-making business would take notice.  You can definitely make a wonderful & tasteful product without adding the trash.

The Janette Oke series prequels and series is the most delightful movie collection I have ordered in a long time. It reminds me of how families do stick together even in the hardest of times.

I have all of the Love Series DVD's.  They are all wonderful.  This one makes a great addition to the ones I already have.  I would recommend this series because it is great viewing for the whole family.  It is sad to see how hard life was in the prairie days, but joyful to see how close families were despite illness, death of family members, hunger, famines and other stressful times.  We should all be thankful for the many luxuries we enjoy today and not take them for granted!

Cheesy as all get out. Slow. And worst of all...there is a scene where they dig a well 45' deep and then pump out water using a hand pump. This is technically impossible! Hand pumps can only work to depth of ~34 feet (then they pull a vacuum).

But I watched it because my wife asked me....it took my love's everlasting courage to not fall asleep.

How is everyone else giving this 5 stars?!  If feel like I'm going crazy.  Hey people, just because it is a Christian themed movie doesn't mean you HAVE to like it.  Come on, let's demand better quality!
